Free Cash Flow.description: Wise investors seek consistent and increasing Free Cash Flow (FCF), ideally greater than 15%-20%. High FCF is a hallmark of strong financial health and reinvestment potential.

Free Cash Flow Slope.description: A positive FCF slope indicates that a company is improving its ability to generate cash over time. Look for companies with consistent growth year-over-year.

Owner's Earnings.description: This measures earnings after capital expenditures. Increasing Owner’s Earnings reflects true economic earnings. Favor values rising steadily over multiple years.

Net Income Growth.description: Strong companies show consistent Net Income growth. Look for positive and accelerating earnings over time.

Operating Margin.description: Operating Margin reveals how efficiently a company turns sales into profits. Great companies maintain >15% over long periods.

Gross Margin.description: Gross Margin reflects core profitability before expenses. Look for margins >30% that remain stable or improve over time.

Return on Equity (ROE).description: ROE measures return on shareholders’ equity. High-quality businesses often have ROEs >15%-20% consistently.

Return on Assets (ROA).description: ROA shows how effectively assets are used to generate profit. A strong ROA is typically >5%-10%.

ROIC vs WACC.description: When ROIC exceeds WACC by a wide margin, the company is creating value. Target an ROIC-WACC spread of >2%-5%.

FCF Margin.description: FCF Margin = Free Cash Flow / Revenue. World-class businesses often post FCF Margins above 15%.

Debt-to-Equity Ratio.description: Lower Debt-to-Equity is better. Target companies with a ratio <1 and strong equity buffers.

Interest Coverage Ratio.description: A higher Interest Coverage Ratio shows the firm can easily pay interest. Look for >5 to be safe.

Net Debt to EBITDA.description: Low Net Debt/EBITDA indicates lower risk and more financial flexibility. The best companies are below 1.

Shares Outstanding Slope.description: Share count reductions (buybacks) benefit long-term shareholders. Seek negative slopes.

Share Buybacks (Average $).description: Aggressive but sensible share buybacks reflect confidence. Measured in billions.

Revenue Growth Rate.description: Sustainable growth is key. Seek >5% annual growth in revenue for quality businesses.

EPS Growth Rate.description: Earnings per share (EPS) growth reflects underlying value creation. Top firms post >10% EPS growth.

CapEx Trend (Positive Slope).description: Upward CapEx trends signal strategic investment. Look for a steady increase aligned with growth.

R&D as % of Revenue.description: R&D drives innovation. Strong companies often spend >5% of revenue on R&D (especially tech/healthcare).

Current Ratio.description: The Current Ratio assesses short-term liquidity. A healthy range is typically 1.5 to 3.

Quick Ratio.description: This ratio excludes inventory. Target companies that can pay short-term liabilities quickly.

OCF to Liabilities.description: Operating Cash Flow vs Liabilities shows ability to meet obligations from operations. Look for >0.5.

Net Income vs OCF Ratio.description: High-quality earnings are backed by cash. The ratio should ideally be close to 1 or higher.

Accrual Ratio.description: Lower accrual ratios are better. High accruals may signal earnings manipulation or poor cash flow.

FCF Slope Stability.description: This measures how steady the FCF increase is over time. Positive, stable growth is rewarded.

ROE Std Dev.description: Standard deviation of ROE shows consistency. Lower variability means steadier performance.

EPS Z-Score.description: EPS Z-score helps detect outliers and earnings volatility. Higher Z-scores suggest steady performance.
